document.docAuthor: Peng, Lingfei, Xiang, Jiawei & Liu, Qifei
document.docTitle: Zaischnopsis nivalinota Peng & Xiang & Liu 2018, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Three new species of Zaischnopsis Ashmead (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea: Eupelmidae) from Southern China, with redescription of Zaischnopsis tubatius (Walker)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Three new species of Zaischnopsis Ashmead (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea: Eupelmidae) from Southern China, with redescription of Zaischnopsis tubatius (Walker)

heading.emphasis:
Zaischnopsis nivalinota Peng & Xiang
, sp. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.
Holotype ♀ ( FAFU ): Longtangshan , Qingliangfeng , Zhejiang Prov.,
VII.2013
, Malaise trap
.
Paratype : Longtangshan , Qingliangfeng , Zhejiang Prov.,
VIII.2013
, Malaise trap ( 1♀ FAFU )
.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 21‒29.
Zaischnopsis nivalinota
. 21, body, lateral; 22, mesosoma, dorsal; 23, head, frontal; 24, head, lateral; 25, head, dorsal; 26, fore wing; 27, propodeum, dorsal (arrow points to broadly U-sharped anterior margin of propodeum); 28, gaster, dorsal; 29, tibia and tarsi of hind leg.

subSubSection.paragraph: Gaster longer than mesosoma, elongate-lanceolate ( Fig. 28 ); Gt 1 and Gt 2 V-like emarginate, Gt 3 and Gt 4 broadly U-like emarginate, Gt 5 shallowly emarginate, Gt 6 convex, syntergum tapered to apex; ovipositor sheath exserted for distance equal to length of basal metatarsomere ( Fig. 42 ).

Variation. The paratype is 4.6 mm in length; scrobal depression separated from anterior ocellus by a distance about 0.7× diameter of anterior ocellus; distance between posterior ocellus and compound eye is very narrow, OOL: POL: LOL: MPOD = 1: 7: 13: 12. The hyaline spot of the fore wing of the paratype is not as white as for the holotype , but more light brown, and the mesoscutum is darker green with less metallic luster.

Remarks. The fore wing color pattern resembles that of
Z. stom
( Fig. 51 ), but the hyaline spot of
Z. stom
is triangular.
Etymology. The species name is from the Latin word “ nivalis ”, which means snowy, and the Latin word “ nota ”, which means a mark, in reference to the white spot behind the marginal vein.
